0.Name: Fuel Blend Plants
0.Drivers for planned retirements: Regulatory non-compliance and clean energy targets
0.Secondary drivers: Compliance with federal coal ash pond regulations; State net-zero targets; Utility-driven clean energy transitions; Conversion to burning natural gas
0.Planned retirement: 39 plants, 17.05% of capacity, 45.3% with planned retirement
0.Vulnerabilities: Most plants burn alternative fuels, including natural gas, oil and petroleum derivatives. Around 26% primarily use alternative coal fuels such as waste coal and recycled coal. All plants are situated in grids heavily reliant on natural gas and half are located in states with Democratic governors.
0.Barriers: Plants are in counties with a significant swing in public opinion since 2018 towards favouring coal power and 95% are in states with Republican legislatures.

1.Name: Retrofitted but Vulnerable Plants
1.Drivers for planned retirements: Only partial retirements planned; economic unviability and renewable competition
1.Secondary drivers: High operational costs and economic pressures from cheaper renewable energy; Lower profitability and limited remaining lifespan due to required upgrades or retrofits; Presence in disadvantaged communities
1.Planned retirement: 3 plants, 3.93% of capacity, 19.13% with planned retirement
1.Vulnerabilities: Plants face challenges with low cash flows and high operational expenses. Located near abundant, more affordable renewable alternatives. All plants within 3 miles of highly disadvantaged communities.
1.Barriers: Heavily invested in emissions control technology retrofits and younger than average (38 years).

2.Name: Democratic Majority Plants
2.Drivers for planned retirements: Political and regulatory pressure for clean energy transitions
2.Secondary drivers: Strong state-level emissions or clean energy mandates; Pressure from environmental groups and state regulators; Uneconomic compared with renewables due to stringent air pollution standards
2.Planned retirement: 14 plants, 5.07% of capacity, 78.57% with planned retirement
2.Vulnerabilities: All plants located in Democratic-majority states with populations favoring retirements. Highest % of planned retirements (79% of plants, 90% of capacity).
2.Barriers: Plants have high average cashflows, younger (42 years), most retiring at around 50 years old. Limited health impacts and mostly not in disadvantaged communities.

3.Name: High Health Impact Plants
3.Drivers for planned retirements: Air-quality related public health concerns and environmental regulations
3.Secondary drivers: High SO2 and PM2.5 emissions driving health impacts; Substantial contribution to public health issues in disadvantaged communities; Economic difficulties due to compliance with environmental regulations
3.Planned retirement: 29 plants, 28.81% of capacity, 50.26% with planned retirement
3.Vulnerabilities: High average SO2 and PM2.5 emissions; highest respiratory-related hospital admissions; oldest plants (avg 45 years).
3.Barriers: Some of the most profitable plants (low forward and operational costs), all located in states with Republican legislatures.

4.Name: Expensive Plants
4.Drivers for planned retirements: High operating costs and environmental retrofit requirements
4.Secondary drivers: High forward costs and environmental compliance expenses; Utility/state climate targets driving retirements; Pressure from utility commitments to renewable energy
4.Planned retirement: 74 plants, 29.18% of capacity, 25.78% with planned retirement
4.Vulnerabilities: Highest average forward costs; 35% owned by entities with ambitious climate targets; Largest CO2 emissions share; Above-average NOx and SO2 emissions rates.
4.Barriers: Significant number of nearby residents, but not in disadvantaged communities; Average retirement age of 60, average plant age 40.

5.Name: Young Plants
5.Planned retirement: 11 plants, 4.12% of capacity, 0% with planned retirement
5.Vulnerabilities: Located in lower-income communities, above-average CO2 emissions, grids with higher wind reliance.
5.Barriers: Average age 32 years (youngest), low criteria air pollutant emissions, limited local impact.

6.Name: Plants in Anti-Coal Regions
6.Secondary drivers: Strong public opposition to coal; State-driven climate goals and renewable energy mandates; Utility carbon-neutral targets by 2050; Aging plants no longer cost-competitive
6.Planned retirement: 14 plants, 5.79% of capacity, 67.1% with planned retirement
6.Vulnerabilities: Ageing plants in counties overwhelmingly opposed to coal; negative cashflows in 2020 despite relative profitability.
6.Barriers: Counties with largest shift in pro-coal sentiment (+6.25% opposed since 2018). Most announced retirement plans (67% of plants, 71.5% of capacity) at 60 years old.

7.Name: Air Quality Offenders
7.Planned retirement: 6 plants, 2.91% of capacity, 0% with planned retirement
7.Vulnerabilities: High SO2, NOx, mercury, PM2.5 emissions; second-highest respiratory hospital admissions; highest group-average capacity factor.
7.Barriers: Low forward costs; located in highest pro-coal counties (60% opposed to emissions limits); zero planned retirements; only two plants owned by entities with emissions reduction targets.
